Worksheet 6

Throughout this page, I will be using Laplace expansion repeatedly to calculate determinants of matrices. If you don't remember/know what that is, here are some resources:

  • YouTube video that computes a 4×44 \times 44×4 matrix determinant
  • Overview of determinants with examples

Problem 1

  1. Denote by TijT_{ij}Tij​ the elementary matrix obtained by exchanging the iii-th row and jjj-th rows. Write TijT_{ij}Tij​ in matrix form. Compute det⁡(Tij)\det\p{T_{ij}}det(Tij​). Prove that det⁡(Tijt)=det⁡(Tij)\det\p{T_{ij}^t} = \det\p{T_{ij}}det(Tijt​)=det(Tij​). Prove that Tij−1=TijT_{ij}^{-1} = T_{ij}Tij−1​=Tij​.

  2. Denote by Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m) the elementary matrix obtained by multiplying the iii-th row by a scalar mmm. Write Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m) in matrix for. Compute det⁡(Di(m))\det\p{D_i\p{m}}det(Di​(m)). Prove that det⁡(Di(m)t)=det⁡(Di(m))\det\p{D_i\p{m}^t} = \det\p{D_i\p{m}}det(Di​(m)t)=det(Di​(m)). Prove that Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m) is invertible if m≠0m \neq 0m=0 with Di(m)−1=Di(m−1)D_i\p{m}^{-1} = D_i\p{m^{-1}}Di​(m)−1=Di​(m−1).

  3. We denote by Lij(m)L_{ij}\p{m}Lij​(m) the elementary matrix obtained by adding to the iii-th row the jjj-th row multiplied by a scalar mmm. Write Lij(m)L_{ij}\p{m}Lij​(m) in matrix form. Compute det⁡(Lij(m))\det\p{L_{ij}\p{m}}det(Lij​(m)). Prove that det⁡(Lij(m)t)=det⁡(Lij(m))\det\p{L_{ij}\p{m}^t} = \det\p{L_{ij}\p{m}}det(Lij​(m)t)=det(Lij​(m)). Prove that Lij(m)−1=Lij(−m)L_{ij}\p{m}^{-1} = L_{ij}\p{-m}Lij​(m)−1=Lij​(−m).

Solution.

  1. To compute TijT_{ij}Tij​, we can just figure out what it does to the standard basis {e1,…,en}\set{e_1, \ldots, e_n}{e1​,…,en​} of Fn\F^nFn. If k∉{i,j}k \notin \set{i, j}k∈/{i,j}, then the iii-th and jjj-th rows of eke_kek​ (or in other words, the iii-th and jjj-th entries of eke_kek​) are both 000, so swapping those rows does nothing. I.e., Tijek=ekT_{ij} e_k = e_kTij​ek​=ek​. However, if k=ik = ik=i, then we swap a 111 in the iii-th entry with a 000 in the jjj-th entry, so Tijei=ejT_{ij} e_i = e_jTij​ei​=ej​. Similarly, Tijej=eiT_{ij} e_j = e_iTij​ej​=ei​. Thus, TijT_{ij}Tij​ looks like

    Tij=(Tije1⋯Tijei⋯Tijej⋯Tijen)=(1⋱0⋯1⋮⋱⋮1⋯0⋱1).\begin{aligned} T_{ij} &= \begin{pmatrix} T_{ij}e_1 & \cdots & T_{ij}e_i & \cdots & T_{ij}e_j & \cdots & T_{ij}e_n \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ & \ddots \\ & & 0 & \cdots & 1 \\ & & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ & & 1 & \cdots & 0 \\ & & & & & \ddots \\ & & & & & & 1 \end{pmatrix}. \end{aligned}Tij​​=(Tij​e1​​⋯​Tij​ei​​⋯​Tij​ej​​⋯​Tij​en​​)=⎝⎛​1​⋱​0⋮1​⋯⋱⋯​1⋮0​⋱​1​⎠⎞​.​

    Most entries are 000 except on the diagonal and the 111's the were moved off the diagonal. The off-diagonal 111's have indices (i,j)\p{i, j}(i,j) and (j,i)\p{j, i}(j,i).

    To compute the determinant, we perform Laplace expansion on the iii-th column first. Assuming i<ji < ji<j, this expansion gives

    det⁡(Tij)=(−1)j+idet⁡(1⋱1⋯1⋱⋮0⋱1).\det\p{T_{ij}} = \p{-1}^{j+i} \det \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ & \ddots \\ & & 1 & \cdots & 1 \\ & & & \ddots & \vdots \\ & & & & 0 \\ & & & & & \ddots \\ & & & & & & 1 \end{pmatrix}.det(Tij​)=(−1)j+idet⎝⎛​1​⋱​1​⋯⋱​1⋮0​⋱​1​⎠⎞​.

    The matrix in the determinant is the minor we get from removing the jjj-th row and iii-th column. Since the jjj-th row is below the top-right 111, its row index doesn't change. However, because the iii-column is to the left, we shifted it to the left by 111. Thus, the 111 has index (i,j−1)\p{i, j-1}(i,j−1). Laplace expanding in the (j−1)\p{j-1}(j−1)-th column gives

    det⁡(Tij)=(−1)j+i(−1)i+(j−1)det⁡(11⋱1)=(−1)2j+2i−1=−1.\det\p{T_{ij}} = \p{-1}^{j+i} \p{-1}^{i+\p{j-1}} \det \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ & 1 \\ & & \ddots \\ & & & 1\end{pmatrix} = \p{-1}^{2j+2i-1} = -1.det(Tij​)=(−1)j+i(−1)i+(j−1)det⎝⎛​1​1​⋱​1​⎠⎞​=(−1)2j+2i−1=−1.

    Here, we used the fact that det⁡In=1\det I_n = 1detIn​=1.

    Next, det⁡(Tijt)=det⁡(Tij)\det\p{T_{ij}^t} = \det\p{T_{ij}}det(Tijt​)=det(Tij​) since this is true for any matrix (or alternatively, you can say that TijT_{ij}Tij​ is symmetric, so it's equal to its transpose).

    Lastly, to show that TijT_{ij}Tij​ is its own inverse, we can just check it on a basis. If k∉{i,j}k \notin \set{i, j}k∈/{i,j}, then

    Tij(Tijek)=Tijek=ek.T_{ij}\p{T_{ij}e_k} = T_{ij}e_k = e_k.Tij​(Tij​ek​)=Tij​ek​=ek​.

    And for k=ik = ik=i,

    Tij(Tijei)=Tij(ej)=eiT_{ij}\p{T_{ij}e_i} = T_{ij}\p{e_j} = e_iTij​(Tij​ei​)=Tij​(ej​)=ei​

    and similarly for k=jk = jk=j. Thus, Tij2=InT_{ij}^2 = I_nTij2​=In​ holds on a basis, and by linearity, it holds everywhere, so Tij−1=TijT_{ij}^{-1} = T_{ij}Tij−1​=Tij​.

  2. Like before, we can compute Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m) on a basis. If k≠ik \neq ik=i, then Di(m)ek=ekD_i\p{m}e_k = e_kDi​(m)ek​=ek​. Otherwise, Di(m)ei=meiD_i\p{m}e_i = me_iDi​(m)ei​=mei​, so

    Di(m)=(1⋱m⋱1).D_i\p{m} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ & \ddots \\ & & m \\ & & & \ddots \\ & & & & 1 \end{pmatrix}.Di​(m)=⎝⎛​1​⋱​m​⋱​1​⎠⎞​.

    Here, Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m) is 000 except on the diagonal. At the (i,i)\p{i, i}(i,i)-th entry, it has an mmm, and it has a 111 everywhere else on the diagonal. Since the determinant of an upper-triangular matrix is just the product of the diagonal entries (you can prove this by induction and Laplace expansion),

    det⁡(Di(m))=1×⋯×m×⋯×1=m.\det\p{D_i\p{m}} = 1 \times \cdots \times m \times \cdots \times 1 = m.det(Di​(m))=1×⋯×m×⋯×1=m.

    Like before, det⁡(Di(m)t)=det⁡(Di(m))\det\p{D_i\p{m}^t} = \det\p{D_i\p{m}}det(Di​(m)t)=det(Di​(m)) since it's symmetric. Lastly, if m≠0m \neq 0m=0, then we can just check that Di(m−1)D_i\p{m^{-1}}Di​(m−1) is an inverse on a basis. If k≠ik \neq ik=i, then

    Di(m−1)(Di(m)ek)=Di(m−1)ek=ekD_i\p{m^{-1}}\p{D_i\p{m}e_k} = D_i\p{m^{-1}}e_k = e_kDi​(m−1)(Di​(m)ek​)=Di​(m−1)ek​=ek​

    and if k=ik = ik=i,

    Di(m−1)(Di(m)ei)=Di(m−1)(mek)=m(Di(m)−1ei)=mm−1ei=ei.\begin{aligned} D_i\p{m^{-1}}\p{D_i\p{m}e_i} &= D_i\p{m^{-1}}\p{me_k} \\ &= m \p{D_i\p{m}^{-1}e_i} \\ &= mm^{-1}e_i \\ &= e_i. \end{aligned}Di​(m−1)(Di​(m)ei​)​=Di​(m−1)(mek​)=m(Di​(m)−1ei​)=mm−1ei​=ei​.​

    Thus, Di(m−1)D_i\p{m^{-1}}Di​(m−1) is a left-inverse for Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m), and because Di(m)D_i\p{m}Di​(m) is a square matrix, it follows that it's also a right-inverse. In other words, Di(m)−1=Di(m−1)D_i\p{m}^{-1} = D_i\p{m^{-1}}Di​(m)−1=Di​(m−1).

  3. I will assume that i≠ji \neq ji=j. Otherwise, Lii(m)=Di(1+m)L_{ii}\p{m} = D_i\p{1 + m}Lii​(m)=Di​(1+m), which is the previous case.

    When k≠jk \neq jk=j, the jjj-th row of eke_kek​ is 000, so adding the jjj-th row of eke_kek​ to anything doesn't change it. Thus, Lij(m)ek=ekL_{ij}\p{m}e_k = e_kLij​(m)ek​=ek​. On the other hand, if k=jk = jk=j, then we add mmm to the iii-th row of eke_kek​, which gives Lij(m)ej=ej+meiL_{ij}\p{m}e_j = e_j + me_iLij​(m)ej​=ej​+mei​. Hence,

    Lij(m)=(1⋱1⋯m⋱⋮1⋱1).L_{ij}\p{m} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ & \ddots \\ & & 1 & \cdots & m \\ & & & \ddots & \vdots \\ & & & & 1 \\ & & & & & \ddots \\ & & & & & & 1 \end{pmatrix}.Lij​(m)=⎝⎛​1​⋱​1​⋯⋱​m⋮1​⋱​1​⎠⎞​.

    Like before, every entry is 000 except on the diagonal, which are all 111's, and except at the (i,j)\p{i, j}(i,j)-th entry, which is mmm. This is an upper-triangular matrix with all 111's on the diagonal, so its determinant is

    det⁡(Lij(m))=1.\det\p{L_{ij}\p{m}} = 1.det(Lij​(m))=1.

    Note that Lij(m)tL_{ij}\p{m}^tLij​(m)t is a lower-triangular matrix, but the determinant of this matrix has the same property: it's the product of its diagonal entries, so det⁡(Lij(m)t)=1\det\p{L_{ij}\p{m}^t} = 1det(Lij​(m)t)=1 also.

    Lastly, if k≠jk \neq jk=j, then

    Lij(−m)(Lij(m)ek)=Lij(−m)ek=ek,L_{ij}\p{-m}\p{L_{ij}\p{m}e_k} = L_{ij}\p{-m}e_k = e_k,Lij​(−m)(Lij​(m)ek​)=Lij​(−m)ek​=ek​,

    and if k=jk = jk=j,

    Lij(−m)(Lij(m)ej)=Lij(−m)(ej+mei)=Lij(−m)ej+mLij(−m)ei=ej−mei+mei=ej.\begin{aligned} L_{ij}\p{-m}\p{L_{ij}\p{m}e_j} &= L_{ij}\p{-m}\p{e_j + me_i} \\ &= L_{ij}\p{-m}e_j + mL_{ij}\p{-m}e_i \\ &= e_j - me_i + me_i \\ &= e_j. \end{aligned}Lij​(−m)(Lij​(m)ej​)​=Lij​(−m)(ej​+mei​)=Lij​(−m)ej​+mLij​(−m)ei​=ej​−mei​+mei​=ej​.​

    Thus, Lij(−m)L_{ij}\p{-m}Lij​(−m) is a left-inverse and Lij(m)L_{ij}\p{m}Lij​(m) is a square matrix, it is invertible with Lij(m)−1=Lij(−m)L_{ij}\p{m}^{-1} = L_{ij}\p{-m}Lij​(m)−1=Lij​(−m).

Problem 5

Let M∈Mn×n(C)M \in M_{n \times n}\p{\C}M∈Mn×n​(C), define the matrix M‾\conj{M}M via (M‾)ij=Mij‾\p{\conj{M}}_{ij} = \conj{M_{ij}}(M)ij​=Mij​​ for all i,j∈{1,…,n}i, j \in \set{1, \ldots, n}i,j∈{1,…,n}.

  1. Prove that det⁡(M‾)=det⁡(M)‾\det\p{\conj{M}} = \conj{\det\p{M}}det(M)=det(M)​.
  2. Prove that Mt‾=(M‾)t\conj{M^t} = \p{\conj{M}}^tMt=(M)t. Define M∗=Mt‾M^* = \conj{M^t}M∗=Mt.
  3. A matrix Q∈Mn×n(C)Q \in M_{n \times n}\p{\C}Q∈Mn×n​(C) is called unitary if QQ∗=InQQ^* = I_nQQ∗=In​. Prove that if QQQ is unitary, then ∣det⁡Q∣=1\abs{\det Q} = 1∣detQ∣=1.
Solution.

The definition of the determinant we're using is

det⁡(M)=∑j=1n(−1)i+jMijdet⁡(M^ij),\det\p{M} = \sum_{j=1}^n \p{-1}^{i+j} M_{ij} \det\p{\widehat{M}_{ij}},det(M)=j=1∑n​(−1)i+jMij​det(Mij​),

where i∈{1,…,n}i \in \set{1, \ldots, n}i∈{1,…,n} is any index, M^ij\widehat{M}_{ij}Mij​ is the minor of MMM we get from removing the iii-th row and jjj-th column (i.e., the row and column that contains MijM_{ij}Mij​). Thus, if MMM is an n×nn \times nn×n matrix, then M^ij\widehat{M}_{ij}Mij​ is an (n−1)×(n−1)\p{n-1} \times \p{n-1}(n−1)×(n−1) matrix.

  1. We prove this by induction. The base case is n=1n = 1n=1, where M=(m11)M = \p{m_{11}}M=(m11​). Then

    det⁡(M‾)=det⁡(m11‾)=m11‾=det⁡(M)‾,\det\p{\conj{M}} = \det\p{\conj{m_{11}}} = \conj{m_{11}} = \conj{\det\p{M}},det(M)=det(m11​​)=m11​​=det(M)​,

    so the base case holds. For the inductive step, assume that det⁡(N‾)=det⁡(N)‾\det\p{\conj{N}} = \conj{\det\p{N}}det(N)=det(N)​ for any n×nn \times nn×n matrix NNN. We need to show it holds for any (n+1)×(n+1)\p{n+1} \times \p{n+1}(n+1)×(n+1) matrix. Let MMM be an (n+1)×(n+1)\p{n+1} \times \p{n+1}(n+1)×(n+1) matrix. Then

    det⁡(M‾)=∑j=1n(−1)i+jMij‾det⁡(Mij‾^).\det\p{\conj{M}} = \sum_{j=1}^n \p{-1}^{i+j} \conj{M_{ij}} \det\p{\widehat{\conj{M_{ij}}}}.det(M)=j=1∑n​(−1)i+jMij​​det(Mij​​​).

    Note that Mij‾^\widehat{\conj{M_{ij}}}Mij​​​ is an n×nn \times nn×n matrix, so by the inductive hypothesis,

    det⁡(Mij‾^)=det⁡(Mij^)‾.\det\p{\widehat{\conj{M_{ij}}}} = \conj{\det\p{\widehat{M_{ij}}}}.det(Mij​​​)=det(Mij​​)​.

    Also, recall that complex conjugation is additive and multiplicative: for z,w∈Cz, w \in \Cz,w∈C, we have z+w‾=z‾=w‾\conj{z + w} = \conj{z} = \conj{w}z+w​=z=w and zw‾=z‾w‾\conj{zw} = \conj{z} \conj{w}zw=zw. Lastly, note that (−1)i+j‾=(−1)i+j\conj{\p{-1}^{i+j}} = \p{-1}^{i+j}(−1)i+j​=(−1)i+j since it's a real number. Putting everything together,

    det⁡(M‾)=∑j=1n(−1)i+jMij‾det⁡(M^ij‾)=∑j=1n(−1)i+j‾Mij‾det⁡(Mij^)‾=∑j=1n(−1)i+jMijdet⁡(Mij^)‾=det⁡(M)‾.\begin{aligned} \det\p{\conj{M}} &= \sum_{j=1}^n \p{-1}^{i+j} \conj{M_{ij}} \det\p{\conj{\widehat{M}_{ij}}} \\ &= \sum_{j=1}^n \conj{\p{-1}^{i+j}} \conj{M_{ij}} \conj{\det\p{\widehat{M_{ij}}}} \\ &= \conj{\sum_{j=1}^n \p{-1}^{i+j} M_{ij} \det\p{\widehat{M_{ij}}}} \\ &= \conj{\det\p{M}}. \end{aligned}det(M)​=j=1∑n​(−1)i+jMij​​det(Mij​​)=j=1∑n​(−1)i+j​Mij​​det(Mij​​)​=j=1∑n​(−1)i+jMij​det(Mij​​)​=det(M)​.​

  2. Recall that (At)ij=Aji\p{A^t}_{ij} = A_{ji}(At)ij​=Aji​ for any matrix AAA. Thus,

    (Mt‾)ij=(Mt)ij‾=Mji‾=(M‾)ji=((M‾)t)ij.\p{\conj{M^t}}_{ij} = \conj{\p{M^t}_{ij}} = \conj{M_{ji}} = \p{\conj{M}}_{ji} = \p{\p{\conj{M}}^t}_{ij}.(Mt)ij​=(Mt)ij​​=Mji​​=(M)ji​=((M)t)ij​.

  3. Recall that if A,BA, BA,B are square, then det⁡(AB)=det⁡(A)det⁡(B)\det\p{AB} = \det\p{A} \det\p{B}det(AB)=det(A)det(B). Thus, if we compute the determinant on both sides of QQ∗=InQQ^* = I_nQQ∗=In​, then

    det⁡(Q)det⁡(Q∗)=det⁡(QQ∗)=det⁡(In)=1.\det\p{Q} \det\p{Q^*} = \det\p{QQ^*} = \det\p{I_n} = 1.det(Q)det(Q∗)=det(QQ∗)=det(In​)=1.

    But by the first part,

    det⁡(Q∗)=det⁡(Qt‾)=det⁡(Qt)‾=det⁡(Q)‾.\det\p{Q^*} = \det\p{\conj{Q^t}} = \conj{\det\p{Q^t}} = \conj{\det\p{Q}}.det(Q∗)=det(Qt​)=det(Qt)​=det(Q)​.

    Lastly, recall that if z∈Cz \in \Cz∈C, then zz‾=∣z∣2z\conj{z} = \abs{z}^2zz=∣z∣2, so

    1=det⁡(Q)det⁡(Q∗)=det⁡(Q)det⁡(Q)‾=∣det⁡(Q)∣2,1 = \det\p{Q} \det\p{Q^*} = \det\p{Q} \conj{\det\p{Q}} = \abs{\det\p{Q}}^2,1=det(Q)det(Q∗)=det(Q)det(Q)​=∣det(Q)∣2,

    which implies that ∣det⁡(Q)∣=1\abs{\det\p{Q}} = 1∣det(Q)∣=1.
